Wipeout 2097, released in 1996, was a significant advancement in video game technology, particularly in the field of 3D graphics. The game utilized a sophisticated polygon rendering engine that allowed for smooth and detailed environments, which were a leap forward from the more rudimentary graphics of its predecessor. This engine was capable of handling complex geometric shapes and dynamic lighting effects, providing a visually immersive experience for players. The use of texture mapping further enhanced the realism of the game, as it allowed for detailed surfaces on both the racing tracks and the vehicles.  Another notable aspect of Wipeout 2097 was its advanced anti-gravity physics. The game featured futuristic hovercrafts that raced at high speeds, and the physics engine was designed to simulate the unique handling and momentum of these vehicles. This required precise calculations to ensure that the crafts responded accurately to player inputs while maintaining a sense of speed and fluidity. The result was a gameplay experience that felt both challenging and rewarding, as players navigated the intricacies of each track.  The audio technology in Wipeout 2097 also set it apart from other games of its time. The game featured an electronic soundtrack that included tracks from well-known artists, which was a novel concept in gaming. This soundtrack was not only a marketing highlight but also integrated seamlessly with the game's fast-paced action, enhancing the overall atmosphere. The audio design extended to the sound effects, which were crisp and clear, adding to the intensity of the racing experience.  Wipeout 2097's technological advancements in graphics, physics, and audio set a high standard for future racing games. Its influence can be seen in many modern titles that strive to combine visual fidelity with engaging gameplay mechanics. Three related subjects are the evolution of racing game physics, the impact of electronic music on video games, and the development of 3D graphics engines.
